p.text: [Div 2 insrt Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[40], effective 1 January 2009]
Credibility evidence about a witness is not admissible.
Specific exceptions to the credibility rule are as follows:
evidence adduced in cross-examination ( sections 103 and 104 )
evidence in rebuttal of denials (section 106)
evidence to re-establish credibility (section 108)
evidence of persons with specialised knowledge (section 108C)
character of accused persons (section 110)
Other provisions of this Act, or of other laws, may operate as further exceptions.
Sections 108A and 108B deal with the admission of credibility evidence about a person who has made a previous representation but is not a witness.
ALRC 38 para 179
This section is known as the credibility rule for the purposes of the Act: see the Dictionary. The Dictionary also contains a definition of “credibility”.
Legislation cited in [50,917.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 101A(b).

Evidence relevant to the credibility of a witness is inadmissible in chief if either that is its sole relevance: R v Heron [2000] NSWCCA 312; BC200004837 ; see also R v Milat (NSWSC, Hunt CJ, 70114/1994, 23 April 1996, unreported, BC9607720); or if it is not also independently admissible in relation to any other relevant purpose: see s 101A(b) .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,920] s 103 Exception: cross-examination as to credibility

p.text: The credibility rule does not apply to evidence adduced in cross-examination of a witness if the evidence could substantially affect the assessment of the credibility of the witness.
[subs (1) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[41], effective 1 January 2009]
Without limiting the matters to which the court may have regard for the purposes of subsection (1) , it is to have regard to:
whether the evidence tends to prove that the witness knowingly or recklessly made a false representation when the witness was under an obligation to tell the truth, and
the period that has elapsed since the acts or events to which the evidence relates were done or occurred.
[subs (2) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[42], effective 1 January 2009]
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 819
ALRC 38 para 179(a)

level.toc-caption: [50,920.15] Evidence which could substantially affect the credibility of a witness

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,920.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 102, 103.

heading.title: Evidence which could substantially affect the credibility of a witness

p.text: The purpose of cross-examination as to credit is to show that a witness ought not be believed on their oath: Wren v Emmett Contractors Pty Ltd (1969) 43 ALJR 213 at 220-221 per Windeyer J; see also Bickel v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1981) 2 NSWLR 474 at 494; Wentworth v Rogers (No 10) (1987) 8 NSWLR 398 esp at 408 . Its purpose is not to prejudice the tribunal of fact against the witness: R v Slack (2003) 139 A Crim R 314; [2003] NSWCCA 93; BC200301493 . The combined effect of ss 102 and 103 is to limit the admissibility of potentially relevant credibility evidence unless it could substantially affect the court’s assessment of the witness’ credibility. The sections have the capacity to materially restrict the scope of cross-examination on credibility issues. The capacity of the evidence to “substantially affect” credibility requires more than a rational capacity to affect the assessment. The court must form an opinion about the facts that the cross-examination is calculated to elicit. It must decide whether those facts would be capable of substantially affecting the credibility of the witness.

It is common in criminal proceedings for a trial judge to be called upon to exercise a discretion in the course of cross-examination about the previous criminal convictions of a witness. Prior to the enactment of the Evidence Act 1995, it had been held that evidence of convictions was admissible in relation to credit, on the basis that a conviction for any offence against the law may have some effect on the credit of a witness: see Bugg v Day (1949) 79 CLR 442 at 458 per Latham CJ, at 471 per McTiernan J and at 475 per Williams J; 23 ALJR 508; BC4900470 . Dixon J (CLR at 467) expressed a more restricted view that questions about the previous convictions of a witness could not be used to discredit the witness if the nature of the offences did not tend to weaken the witness’ credit.

For the purpose of the section in its current form, the fact that a conviction may have “some effect” on the issue of credit falls short of the requirement that the evidence has the capacity to “substantially affect” the credibility of the witness. The section provides a safeguard particularly in relation to cross-examination going to previous criminal convictions by permitting the court to limit such cross-examination to offences which, of their very nature, tend to weaken confidence in the witness's credit by reflecting upon his character or trustworthiness to the point where it can be said that evidence of such convictions could substantially affect the credibility of the witness: cf Bugg v Day , above, CLR at 467.

level.toc-caption: [50,920.25] Tendering documents during cross examination as to credibility

heading.title: Tendering documents during cross examination as to credibility

p.text: A document can constitute “evidence adduced in cross examination” for the purposes of s 103. Accordingly, a document can be admitted as to credit pursuant to s 103 even if it does not satisfy one of the other paths to admissibility of documents under another section of the Act: R v Aslett [2006] NSWCCA 49; BC200601952 ; McMahon v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd (No 5) [2012] NSWSC 218; BC201201445 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,925] s 104 Further protections: cross-examination of accused

p.text: This section applies only to credibility evidence in a criminal proceeding and so applies in addition to section 103 .
[subs (1) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[43], effective 1 January 2009]
A defendant must not be cross-examined about a matter that is relevant to the assessment of the defendant's credibility, unless the court gives leave.
[subs (2) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[44], effective 1 January 2009]
Despite subsection (2) , leave is not required for cross-examination by the prosecutor about whether the defendant:
is biased or has a motive to be untruthful, or
is, or was, unable to be aware of or recall matters to which his or her evidence relates, or
has made a prior inconsistent statement.
Leave must not be given for cross-examination by the prosecutor under subsection (2) unless evidence adduced by the defendant has been admitted that:
tends to prove that a witness called by the prosecutor has a tendency to be untruthful, and
is relevant solely or mainly to the witness’s credibility.
[subs (4) subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[45], effective 1 January 2009]
A reference in subsection (4) to evidence does not include a reference to evidence of conduct in relation to:
the events in relation to which the defendant is being prosecuted, or
the investigation of the offence for which the defendant is being prosecuted.
[subs (5) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[46], effective 1 January 2009]
Leave is not to be given for cross-examination by another defendant unless:
the evidence that the defendant to be cross-examined has given includes evidence adverse to the defendant seeking leave to cross-examine, and
that evidence has been admitted.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,930] s 105 Further protections: defendants making unsworn statements

leg:heading.title: Further protections: defendants making unsworn statements

p.text: The Commonwealth Act includes a provision that will only apply in proceedings in a federal court sitting in Norfolk Island. It sets out the situations in which where a defendant in a criminal proceeding has made an unsworn statement evidence may be adduced from a person relating solely to the credibility of the defendant.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,935] s 106 Exception: rebutting denials by other evidence

leg:heading.title: Exception: rebutting denials by other evidence

p.text: The credibility rule does not apply to evidence that is relevant to a witness’s credibility and that is adduced otherwise than from the witness if:
in cross-examination of the witness:
the substance of the evidence was put to the witness, and
the witness denied, or did not admit or agree to, the substance of the evidence, and
the court gives leave to adduce the evidence.
Leave under subsection (1)(b) is not required if the evidence tends to prove that the witness:
is biased or has a motive for being untruthful, or
has been convicted of an offence, including an offence against the law of a foreign country, or
has made a prior inconsistent statement, or
is, or was, unable to be aware of matters to which his or her evidence relates, or
has knowingly or recklessly made a false representation while under an obligation, imposed by or under an Australian law or a law of a foreign country, to tell the truth.
[s 106 subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[47], effective 1 January 2009]
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 819
ALRC 38 paras 179(c), 180(c)
ALRC 02 paras 12.79–12.83
Legislation cited in [50,935.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 106(1), s 106(2).

A precondition of admissibility (under s 106(1) ) is that the substance of the proposed evidence has been put to, and not substantially admitted by, the witness: R v Spiteri (2004) 61 NSWLR 369; [2004] NSWCCA 321; BC200406903 . If that condition has been met, no leave is required to adduce evidence of the kinds referred to in s 106(2) . Subject to the same threshold condition, evidence of other matters may be adduced with leave. A possible subject matter for the grant of leave could be matters relating to the mental or physical disability of a witness: R v Gunewardene [1951] 2 KB 600; [1951] 2 All ER 290 ; cf Toohey v Metropolitan Police Cmr [1965] AC 595 at 609 .
Legislation cited in [50,935.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Crimes Act 1900 s 413.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 106(1).

At common law answers given in cross-examination on collateral matters relevant only to credit could generally not be contradicted by affirmative evidence: R v Umanski [1961] VR 242 ; Harris v Tippett (1811) 2 Camp 637; 170 ER 1277 . (Some guidance as to what constitutes a collateral issue is found in the judgment of Pollock CB in Attorney-General v Hitchcock (1847) 1 Exch 91 at 99; 154 ER 38 . Another illustration, that identifies the potential limits of even credit relevance, is Piddington v Bennett and Wood Pty Ltd (1940) 63 CLR 533 at 558–59 .) The general common law exclusionary rule is subject to established, but not exhaustively settled, exceptions: R v Funderbunk [1990] 2 All ER 482; [1990] 1 WLR 587 ; Natta v Canham (1991) 32 FCR 282; 104 ALR 143 ; Urban Transport Authority of New South Wales v Nweiser (1991) 28 NSWLR 471. For example, a witness may be cross-examined about bias or partiality, and prior convictions. A witness's general reputation for untruthfulness could also be independently proved at common law (in New South Wales see now Crimes Act 1900 s 413 ): Attorney-General v Hitchcock (1847) 1 Exch 91; 154 ER 38; Thomas v David (1836) 7 C & P 350; The Queen's Case (1820) 2 Brod & Bing 284 at 311–15; 129 ER 976; R v Shore (1888) 16 Cox CC 503; R v Hunter [1956] VLR 31; [1955] ALR 786 ; R v Umanski [1961] VR 242 . All of these matters are either expressly, or potentially, within the scope of the credibility evidence conditionally permitted by s 106(1) .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,940] s 107 Exception: application of certain provisions to makers of representations

leg:heading.title: Exception: application of certain provisions to makers of representations

p.text: [s 107 rep Act 55 of 1997 s 3 and Sch 1]
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 721
ALRC 38 para 131(c)

level.toc-caption: [50,940.10] Credibility evidence relating to hearsay representations

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,940.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 Pt 3.2, s 102.

heading.title: Credibility evidence relating to hearsay representations

p.text: Some hearsay statements are admissible under Pt 3.2 notwithstanding that the maker of the statement is not called to give evidence. The present section assumes that the credibility rule would otherwise apply to evidence so admitted — and permits evidence of the matters that could have been the subject of cross-examination if the maker had been called. However, the credibility rule as stated in s 102 , only renders inadmissible evidence going to the credibility of a witness. It is arguable that the uncalled maker of a hearsay statement is not a “witness”(see the definition in the Dictionary) and thus the credibility rule has no application at all.
The credibility rule does not apply to evidence adduced in re-examination of a witness.
[subs (2) rep Act 55 of 1997 s 3 and Sch 1]
The Commonwealth Act includes a subsection referring to section 105 of that Act.
The credibility rule does not apply to evidence of a prior consistent statement of a witness if:
evidence of a prior inconsistent statement of the witness has been admitted, or

it is or will be suggested (either expressly or by implication) that evidence given by the witness has been fabricated or re-constructed (whether deliberately or otherwise) or is the result of a suggestion, and the court gives leave to adduce the evidence of the prior consistent statement.
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 685
ALRC 38 para 144(a)
Legislation cited in [50,945.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 108(3)(b).

The provisions of s 108(3)(b) confirm the common law rule that prior consistent statements may be used to rebut a suggestion of invention: Nominal Defendant v Clements (1960) 104 CLR 476 at 479; [1960] ALR 701 . Consistent with that position, the timing of the making of the statement is more important than the circumstances in which the statement was made: R v DBG 133 A Crim R 227; [2002] NSWCCA 328; BC200205266 . However, the section goes further than the common law position by allowing, subject to leave, evidence of the prior consistent statement to be given before the suggestion of fabrication or invention has actually been put to the witness.

The provisions of the section constitute an exception to the credibility rule that evidence which is relevant only to the credibility of a witness is not admissible. The exercise of the discretion under the section depends upon the effect of the evidence on the credibility of the witness: see Graham v R (1998) 195 CLR 606; 157 ALR 404; [1998] HCA 61; BC9804990 ; see also R v Whitmore (1999) 109 A Crim R 51; [1999] NSWCCA 247; BC9905094 .
